verses.text: So Agrippa said to Paul, 'You are permitted to speak for yourself.' Then Paul stretched out his hand and began his defense:
verses.comment: Paul is given the opportunity to defend himself before King Agrippa, continuing the tradition of public testimony (see Acts 24:10). Luke presents Paul’s defense as both historical and theological.

verses.text: "King Agrippa, I consider myself fortunate that I am to make my defense before you today regarding all the accusations made against me by the Jewish people,
verses.comment: Paul addresses Agrippa with respect, reflecting the importance of both proper order and authority in the early Christian community (see also Acts 24:10).

verses.text: especially since you are familiar with all the customs and disputes among the Jews. Therefore, I beg you to listen to me patiently.
verses.comment: Paul recognizes Agrippa's knowledge of Jewish matters, showing respect for tradition and proper authority in spiritual and cultural matters.

verses.text: All the Jews know my way of life from my youth, which I spent from the beginning among my own nation and in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes his deep roots in Jewish tradition (see Acts 22:3), underlining the continuity between his faith and his Jewish heritage.

verses.text: They have known me for a long time, and if they are willing to testify, they know I lived as a Pharisee, according to the strictest party of our religion.
verses.comment: As a Pharisee, Paul was highly observant, illustrating that faithfulness to the Scriptures and tradition is compatible with recognizing Jesus as Messiah.

verses.text: And now I stand here on trial because of my hope in the promise made by God to our ancestors,
verses.comment: The promise refers back to God’s covenant with Abraham and the patriarchs (Gen. 22:18), showing continuity from Israel to the fulfillment in Christ.

verses.text: which our twelve tribes hope to attain, worshiping God night and day. And for this hope, I am accused by the Jews, O King.
verses.comment: The reference to worship ‘night and day’ hints at a continuous, structured liturgy—an important aspect of the early Church’s worship similar to later developed monastic practices.

verses.text: Why is it considered incredible among you that God raises the dead?
verses.comment: Paul appeals to the core belief in the resurrection (see Ezekiel 37:3; Acts 23:8), a foundational doctrine that sees fulfillment in Christ’s Resurrection.

verses.text: I myself was convinced that I ought to do many things opposing the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
verses.comment: Paul’s initial opposition highlights the dramatic nature of his conversion, emphasizing how grace can transform even the most zealous opponent into a servant of Christ.

verses.text: And I did so in Jerusalem; not only did I lock up many of the saints in prisons, receiving authority from the chief priests, but when they were put to death, I cast my vote against them.
verses.comment: Paul admits to persecuting the early believers, showing humility and the power of repentance within the Church (see Acts 8:1, 7:58).

verses.text: Frequently, in all the synagogues, I tried to force them to blaspheme; and being furiously enraged against them, I even pursued them to foreign cities.
verses.comment: 'Force them to blaspheme' suggests attempts to break their fidelity to Christ, showing the seriousness of apostasy and perseverance under persecution.

verses.text: While thus engaged as I journeyed to Damascus with the authority and commission of the chief priests,
verses.comment: Paul's mission is sanctioned by high religious authorities, showing the seriousness of his former opposition.

verses.text: at midday, O King, I saw on the way a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, shining all around me and those journeying with me.
verses.comment: The supernatural light points to divine intervention, and the detail of 'brighter than the sun' recalls Old Testament theophanies (see Daniel 10:6).

verses.text: When we had all fallen to the ground, I heard a voice speaking to me in the Hebrew language, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is hard for you to kick against the goads.'
verses.comment: Jesus’s direct address, 'Why are you persecuting me?' underscores the mystical union between Christ and His followers (see 1 Cor. 12:27).

verses.text: I answered, 'Who are you, Lord?' And the Lord said, 'I am Jesus whom you are persecuting.
verses.comment: This is a direct claim to Christ’s continuing presence with His Church. The Lord identifies Himself intimately with His followers.

verses.text: But rise and stand on your feet; for I have appeared to you for this purpose, to appoint you as a servant and a witness both of what you have seen and what I will show you.
verses.comment: Paul is made both a servant and a witness, echoing Old Testament prophetic callings and elevating apostolic authority as established by Christ.

verses.text: I will rescue you from your people and from the Gentiles—to whom I am sending you,
verses.comment: Jesus promises Paul deliverance, similar to prophetic missions in the Old Testament (Jer. 1:8).

verses.text: to open their eyes, so that they may turn from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and a share among those who are sanctified by faith in me.'
verses.comment: Paul’s mission is to mediate forgiveness and sanctification, showing the transformative power of grace dispensed through Christ’s appointed servants.

verses.text: "So then, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,
verses.comment: Paul’s faithfulness to the vision reflects the importance of obedience to divine revelation.

verses.text: but declared first to those in Damascus, then in Jerusalem, and throughout all the region of Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent, turn to God, and do deeds consistent with repentance.
verses.comment: The call to ‘deeds consistent with repentance’ underscores faith and works together, as taught throughout the New Testament (see Matt. 3:8).

verses.text: For this reason the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.
verses.comment: Paul’s arrest was the result of his proclamation of the Gospel, showing how the message of Christ provoked opposition, as forewarned by Jesus Himself.

verses.text: But to this day I have had the help that comes from God, and so I stand here testifying both to small and great, saying nothing except what the prophets and Moses said would happen:
verses.comment: The consistency between Paul’s message and 'the prophets and Moses' highlights the fulfillment of the Law and the Prophets in Christ.

verses.text: that the Messiah must suffer, and that, being the first to rise from the dead, he would proclaim light both to our people and to the Gentiles."
verses.comment: Paul references Isaiah 53 and Psalm 16, foundational texts concerning the suffering and resurrection of the Messiah. Christ’s resurrection is the key event inaugurating the new covenant.

verses.text: As he was saying these things in his defense, Festus said with a loud voice, 'Paul, you are out of your mind! Your great learning is driving you insane.'
verses.comment: Festus’s reaction echoes the perception of the Gospel as folly to Gentiles (1 Cor. 1:18-23).

verses.text: But Paul said, 'I am not insane, most excellent Festus, but I am speaking words of truth and sober-mindedness.
verses.comment: Paul insists on the rationality and truthfulness of his testimony; faith and reason are in harmony, not opposed.

verses.text: For the king knows about these things, and to him I speak boldly, for I am persuaded that none of these things has escaped his notice; for this has not been done in a corner.
verses.comment: Christianity arose in public — ‘not done in a corner’ — emphasizing the Church's visible, historical nature and continuity.

verses.text: King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you believe."
verses.comment: Paul appeals to prophetic authority and faith in Scripture, inviting Agrippa to faith in Christ as the fulfillment of prophecy.

verses.text: And Agrippa said to Paul, 'Do you think that in such a short time you would persuade me to become a Christian?'
verses.comment: Agrippa’s response shows the recognition and challenge of proclaiming the faith. Evangelism is personal and persistent.

verses.text: Paul said, 'Whether in a short or long time, I pray to God that not only you but also all who hear me today might become such as I am, except for these chains.'
verses.comment: Paul wishes the fullness of Christian life for all listeners, highlighting the universality and missionary impulse of the apostolic Church.

verses.text: The king stood up, and the governor and Bernice and those sitting with them also rose.
verses.comment: This marks the formal end of Paul’s trial before Agrippa, witnessed by several authorities, again underlining the public nature of the Church’s witness.

verses.text: And when they had withdrawn, they began speaking to one another, saying, 'This man is doing nothing worthy of death or imprisonment.'
verses.comment: Official recognition of Paul’s innocence parallels Pilate’s recognition of Jesus’ innocence (see Luke 23:4), cultivating a sense of continuity in redemptive history.

verses.text: And Agrippa said to Festus, 'This man could have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar.'
verses.comment: Paul’s appeal to Caesar opens the way for the Gospel to reach the heart of the Empire. This underscores the Church’s mission to the whole world.
